samsung-com-redesign.name: Samsung.com Redesign
samsung-com-redesign.intro:
Samsung needed help turning a brittle site into smart and flexible system. Our design needed to support individual shoppers across a huge range of products — from stoves to smartphones. I helped lead a team of UX researchers and designers on a cross-country research tour. We used in-home interviews, usability tests, and retail shop-alongs to understand how people research, shop and buy products across the Samsung range.

We then designed a series of reusable content blocks informed by the user pain points and needs. Since it was hard to find non-smartphone products — making other shoppers feel like “second class citizens — we created a new flattened global navigation. Since products in the same range were impossible to tell apart, we made a new product grid focused on key differences. And we eliminated a whole section of the site, moving content showing the product in action from marketing landing pages into the main purchase flow.

Our initial launch resulted in a 40% increase in conversion. When a later shift in strategy made our initial building blocks too restrictive, we deconstructed them into a design system and living styleguide. This lets teams at R/GA and Samsung continue to create much richer pages out of a common set of building blocks.

samsung-retail.name: Samsung Retail
samsung-retail.intro:
Samsung maintains a TV demo area in large retail stores across the country. Over the years, more content and controls appeared without a plan. The experience became bloated and fragile. The goal of this project was to design a simpler interaction model — giving users control without getting in their way. The system also needed to be easier for Samsung to track and maintain.

The design solution revolves around a touchscreen where users can choose the specific content and TVs that interest them. Competitor experiences tend to only have a preset content loop and stuffy touchscreen brochures. The surrounding stations highlight a fluctuating set of features and accessories. These use simple buttons covered by a printed "interface" so store employees can change them on-demand. This approach was inspired by paper prototypes I made in collaboration with our hardware engineers.

The whole system runs on a network built in-house by R/GA. I designed a monitoring and content management dashboard on top of this infrastructure. For the first time, Samsung has real-time visibility into the status of the system. Technicians get alerts exactly when and where errors occur. And Samsung is able to update content without incurring high costs and lead time.

The Samsung Entertainment Experience is now runs at 98% average uptime and consumer understanding of TV features has doubled year over year.
